TITLE: Configuring General Dnsmasq DNS & DHCP Settings
DESCRIPTION: Configures general Dnsmasq settings in OPNsense under Services -> Dnsmasq DNS & DHCP -> General. It specifies the interfaces (LAN, GUEST) for DHCP service, enables DHCP FQDN registration, sets the default domain to 'internal', and enables firewall rule registration for DHCP.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/dnsmasq.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
Interface: LAN, GUEST
DHCP fqdn: X
DHCP default domain: internal
DHCP register firewall rules: X
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Setting API Credentials in Shell Variables (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: Defines and exports the $key and $secret variables to securely store OPNsense API credentials for use in authentication with tools like curl. These credentials are required for API access, and users should replace the demonstrated values with their own. This pattern is used as a prerequisite for executing authenticated requests.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/api.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
key=w86XNZob/8Oq8aC5r0kbNarNtdpoQU781fyoeaOBQsBwkXUt
secret=XeD26XVrJ5ilAc/EmglCRC+0j2e57tRsjHwFepOseySWLM53pJASeTA3
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Querying OPNsense Firmware Status with Python
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use the Python 'requests' library to query the OPNsense firmware status API endpoint (/api/core/firmware/status). It includes importing libraries, setting up credentials and URL, making a GET request with basic authentication and optional SSL certificate verification, parsing the JSON response, and printing relevant status details based on the response content.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/how-tos/api.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# import libraries
import json
import requests

# define endpoint and credentials
api_key = 'w86XNZob/8Oq8aC5hxh2he+vLN00r0kbNarNtdpoQU781fyoeaOBQsBwkXUt'
api_secret = 'puOyw0Ega3xZXeD26XVrJ5WYFepOseySWLM53pJASeTA3'
url = 'https://192.168.1.1/api/core/firmware/status'
 
# request data
r = requests.get(url,
                 verify='OPNsense.pem',
                 auth=(api_key, api_secret))

if r.status_code == 200:
    response = json.loads(r.text)

    if response['status'] == 'ok':
        print ('OPNsense can be upgraded')
        print ('download size : %s' % response['download_size'])
        print ('number of packages : %s' % response['updates'])
        if response['upgrade_needs_reboot'] == '1':
            print ('REBOOT REQUIRED')
    elif 'status_msg' in response:
        print (response['status_msg'])
else:
    print ('Connection / Authentication issue, response received:')
    print r.text
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Firewall Rules - Wireguard (Group) (Site B)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet details the firewall configuration for the Wireguard (Group) interface in Site B.  It is configured to pass traffic with the interface being Wireguard (Group), direction 'in', IPv4, and protocol 'Any'. The source is set to Site A's LAN, and destination to Site B's LAN network, allowing traffic from Site A to Site B.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/wireguard-s2s.rst#_snippet_13



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Fetching Mullvad WireGuard Configuration Using Curl - Shell
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows two curl commands to retrieve WireGuard tunnel configuration from MullvadVPN APIs. The first command fetches tunnel IPs and configurations through Mullvad's standard API while hijacking DNS requests to Mullvad's servers. The second command is an alternative that does not hijack DNS, using JSON authentication headers. Both require substituting YOURACCOUNTNUMBER with the Mullvad account ID and YOURPUBLICKEY with the WireGuard instance public key generated in OPNsense. The output includes the Allowed IPs that must be set in the WireGuard instance configuration.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/wireguard-client-mullvad.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
curl -sSL https://api.mullvad.net/wg/ -d account=YOURACCOUNTNUMBER --data-urlencode pubkey=YOURPUBLICKEY
```

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
curl -sSL https://api.mullvad.net/app/v1/wireguard-keys -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: Token YOURACCOUNTNUMBER" -d '{"pubkey":"YOURPUBLICKEY"}'
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Adding Firewall Rule: Block Local Networks from GUESTNET - OPNsense Configuration
DESCRIPTION: This critical security rule prevents traffic originating from the GUESTNET from reaching the LAN network. It blocks any protocol from the guest network trying to connect to the LAN network segment, ensuring isolation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/guestnet.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: Configuration
CODE:
```
Action: Block (Block this traffic)
Interface: GUESTNET (The GuestNet Interface)
Protocol: any
Source: GUESTNET net
Destination: LAN net
Category: GuestNet Basic Rules (Category used for grouping rules)
Description: Block Local Networks
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Mounting ZFS File System and Resetting Password - Shell
DESCRIPTION: These commands are used for ZFS file systems to enable disk modifications and then reset the root password.  The first command `/sbin/mount -u /` is used to update existing mounts.  The second command `/sbin/zfs mount -a` mounts all ZFS filesystems. The final two commands set a new password and then reboot the machine. The expected input is a confirmation (Y) during the password reset. This needs to be executed when in single user mode.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/troubleshooting/password_reset.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
/sbin/mount -u /
```

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
/sbin/zfs mount -a
```

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
opnsense-shell password
```

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
reboot
```

TITLE: Configuring Firewall Rules - WAN Interface
DESCRIPTION: This snippet outlines the configuration of a firewall rule to permit incoming Wireguard traffic from Site A on the WAN interface. It requires setting the action to Pass, specifying the interface as WAN, setting the direction to In, using IPv4, UDP protocol, setting the source IP, the destination IP, the destination port, and providing a descriptive comment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/wireguard-s2s.rst#_snippet_8



----------------------------------------

TITLE: Testing OPNsense Configd Actions with configctl (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: These shell commands demonstrate how to test the newly defined configd actions for the 'helloworld' service from the command line using the `configctl` utility. They show executing start, stop, status, and restart actions and their expected output.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/examples/api_enable_services.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: Shell
CODE:
```
# configctl helloworld start
OK
# configctl helloworld stop
OK
# configctl helloworld status
hello world is running
# configctl helloworld restart
OK
```

TITLE: Adding IPsec Client Certificates in OPNsense
DESCRIPTION: This snippet guides creating client certificates through OPNsense's certificate management interface. It includes steps to select a CA, set a lifetime, provide a common name, and export the certificate as PKCS12 for use on end-user devices, facilitating certificate-based authentication.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-rw-srv-eaptls.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
Step 4 - Add IPsec Users
------------------------
Go to :menuselection:`System --> Trust --> Certificates` and create a new client certificate.
Click **Add**, select your CA, set the lifetime, specify the Common Name, and save.
Download the certificate as PKCS12 and export it to your end user device.
```

It includes the client's private key, assigned IP addresses (both IPv4 and IPv6), and DNS servers. The peer section specifies the server's public key, allowed IP ranges to route through the tunnel, and the endpoint address with port. This example is intended for reference only and keys should not be reused.

CODE:
```
[Interface]
PrivateKey = 8GboYh0YF3q/hJhoPFoL3HM/ObgOuC8YI6UXWsgWL2M=
Address = 10.10.10.2/32, fd00:1234:abcd:ef09:10:2/128
DNS = 192.168.1.254, fd00:1234:abcd:ef09:1:254

[Peer]
PublicKey = OwdegSTyhlpw7Dbpg8VSUBKXF9CxoQp2gAOdwgqtPVI=
AllowedIPs = 0.0.0.0/0, ::/0
Endpoint = opnsense.example.com:51820
```

TITLE: Diagramming Firewall Rule Processing Order
DESCRIPTION: A blockdiag definition showing the explicit order in which different types of firewall rules are processed in OPNsense: System defined (dotted), Floating rules, Interface groups, and finally Interface-specific rules. Understanding this order is crucial when provisioning rules via OPNcentral.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/vendor/deciso/opncentral.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: blockdiag
CODE:
```
blockdiag {
   System [label="System defined", style = dotted];
   Floating [label="Floating rules"];
   Groups [label="Interface groups"];
   Interfaces [label="Interfaces"];
   System -> Floating -> Groups -> Interfaces;
}
```

TITLE: Defining Suricata Rule for TLS SNI Threat Detection - Suricata Rule - sh
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates a Suricata rule designed to alert on TLS traffic where the Server Name Indication (SNI) matches a known command-and-control (CnC) domain associated with Glupteba malware. Dependencies include Suricata and an up-to-date rule processing engine. The rule inspects packets from the defined home network to any external network, matching on specific SNI contents and related threat metadata. Inputs are network packets; outputs are alert logs generated upon detection of matching traffic. The rule expects correctly defined $HOME_NET and $EXTERNAL_NET variables and works within Suricata's supported platforms.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/ips.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
alert tls $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET TROJAN Observed Glupteba CnC Domain in TLS SNI"; flow:established,to_server; tls_sni; content:"myinfoart.xyz"; depth:13; isdataat:!1,relative; metadata: former_category MALWARE; reference:md5,4cc43c345aa4d6e8fd2d0b6747c3d996; classtype:trojan-activity; sid:2029751; rev:2; metadata:affected_product Windows_XP_Vista_7_8_10_Server_32_64_Bit, attack_target Client_Endpoint, deployment Perimeter, signature_severity Major, created_at 2020_03_30, updated_at 2020_03_30;)
```

TITLE: Setting Dnsmasq DHCP Option dns-server[6] for LAN
DESCRIPTION: Configures the 'dns-server' (option 6) DHCP setting for the LAN interface in OPNsense Dnsmasq under Services -> Dnsmasq DNS & DHCP -> DHCP options. It specifies the DNS server IP address (192.168.1.1, typically the OPNsense Unbound instance) for clients on the LAN.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/dnsmasq.rst#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
Type: Set
Option: dns-server[6]
Interface: LAN
Value: 192.168.1.1
```

TITLE: Testing Nginx WAF with curl (sh)
DESCRIPTION: This command tests the Nginx WAF configuration by sending an HTTP GET request containing common SQL injection keywords in the query parameters. It is used to verify that the WAF is triggered and logs or blocks the request as configured. The expected outcome, if the WAF is properly configured to block such patterns, is an OPNsense error page and corresponding log entries.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/nginx_waf.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
curl "http://example.com/index.php?a=select&b=union&c=from"
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing API Controller with CRUD Operations in PHP
DESCRIPTION: Implements an API controller using the OPNsense ApiMutableModelControllerBase base class to provide RESTful CRUD functionality for the GridExample data model. This controller exposes endpoints for searching, retrieving, adding, updating, deleting, and toggling the enabled state of address records. It leverages base methods such as searchBase, addBase, setBase, getBase, delBase, and toggleBase, simplifying interaction with the underlying XML data model. The controller requires correct $internalModelName and $internalModelClass settings to connect to the model.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/examples/using_grids.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: PHP
CODE:
```
namespace OPNsense\GridExample\Api;

use \OPNsense\Base\ApiMutableModelControllerBase;

class SettingsController extends ApiMutableModelControllerBase
{
    protected static $internalModelName = 'gridexample';
    protected static $internalModelClass = 'OPNsense\GridExample\GridExample';

    public function searchItemAction()
    {
        return $this->searchBase("addresses.address", array('enabled', 'email'), "email");
    }

    public function setItemAction($uuid)
    {
        return $this->setBase("address", "addresses.address", $uuid);
    }

    public function addItemAction()
    {
        return $this->addBase("address", "addresses.address");
    }

    public function getItemAction($uuid = null)
    {
        return $this->getBase("address", "addresses.address", $uuid);
    }

    public function delItemAction($uuid)
    {
        return $this->delBase("addresses.address", $uuid);
    }

    public function toggleItemAction($uuid, $enabled = null)
    {
        return $this->toggleBase("addresses.address", $uuid, $enabled);
    }
}

```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using try, catch, and finally Blocks in PHP
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the try-catch-finally construct with multiple catch blocks including union types for exceptions, demonstrating proper syntax and brace placement. This structure is used for exception handling and cleanup. The snippet depends on PHP's Throwable types and exception hierarchy.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_22

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

try {
    // try body
} catch (FirstThrowableType $e) {
    // catch body
} catch (OtherThrowableType | AnotherThrowableType $e) {
    // catch body
} finally {
    // finally body
}
```

TITLE: Enabling Caddy Admin Endpoint via OPNsense Shell
DESCRIPTION: Sequence of shell commands executed via SSH on the OPNsense device to enable the Caddy admin endpoint. This involves stopping the Caddy service, navigating to the configuration directory, creating a specific configuration file (`admin.global`) with the necessary directive, validating the configuration, and restarting the Caddy service. This endpoint is typically used for advanced debugging and profiling.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/caddy.rst#_snippet_20

LANGUAGE: Shell
CODE:
```
configctl caddy stop
```

LANGUAGE: Shell
CODE:
```
cd /usr/local/etc/caddy/caddy.d/
```

LANGUAGE: Shell
CODE:
```
# Create a new file named admin.global with the content 'admin :2019'
# Example using echo:
# echo 'admin :2019' > admin.global
```

LANGUAGE: Shell
CODE:
```
cd /usr/local/etc/caddy
```

LANGUAGE: Shell
CODE:
```
caddy validate
```

LANGUAGE: Shell
CODE:
```
configctl caddy start
```

TITLE: Define data model XML
DESCRIPTION: This XML snippet defines the data model for the HelloWorld module, specifying the fields and their types within the 'general' container.  It includes attributes like Enabled (BooleanField), SMTPHost (NetworkField), FromEmail and ToEmail (EmailField), and Description (TextField). Each field can have attributes like 'default' and 'Required' for validation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/examples/helloworld.rst#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: xml
CODE:
```
    <items>
        <!-- container -->
        <general>
            <!-- fields -->
            <Enabled type="BooleanField">
                <default>1</default>
                <Required>Y</Required>
            </Enabled>
            <SMTPHost type="NetworkField">
                <Required>Y</Required>
            </SMTPHost>
            <FromEmail type="EmailField">
                <default>sample@example.com</default>
                <Required>Y</Required>
            </FromEmail>
            <ToEmail type="EmailField">
                <Required>Y</Required>
            </ToEmail>
            <Description type="TextField">
                <Required>Y</Required>
            </Description>
        </general>
    </items>
```

TITLE: Configure routing for traffic generated by the router - OPNsense
DESCRIPTION: Configures a floating firewall rule to route traffic originating from the router itself through the VPN gateway. The rule matches traffic originating from the WireGuard VPN interface address and destined for any address except the WireGuard VPN interface network.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/wireguard-selective-routing.rst#_snippet_2

TITLE: Creating Phase 1 Configuration for Mobile Clients in IPsec VPN
DESCRIPTION: This snippet explains configuring Phase 1 parameters such as connection method, key exchange version, interface, and identifier. It also covers choosing the appropriate authentication method, selecting certificates, and setting encryption algorithms including hash and DH group, to establish initial secure communication.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-rw-srv-eaptls.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
Phase 1 General information
---------------------------
========================== ============= ==================================================
 **Connection method**      default       *default is 'Start on traffic'*
 **Key Exchange version**   V2            *only V2 is supported for EAP-TLS*
 **Internet Protocol**      IPv4
 **Interface**              WAN           *choose the interface connected to the internet*
 **Description**            MobileIPsec   *freely chosen description*
========================== ============= ==================================================

Phase 1 proposal (Authentication)
---------------------------------
=========================== ==================== ==============================================
 **Authentication method**   EAP-TLS              *This is the method we want here*
 **My identifier**           Distinguished Name   *Set the FQDN you used within certificate*
 **My Certificate**          Certificate          *Choose the certificate from dropdown list*
=========================== ==================== ==============================================
```

TITLE: Implementing API Controller in PHP for OPNsense
DESCRIPTION: Example of an API controller extending ApiControllerBase that handles a POST request and returns a JSON response. This pattern is used for building RESTful API endpoints in OPNsense.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/controller.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
class TestController extends ApiControllerBase
{
    /**
     * @return array
     */
    public function echoAction()
    {
        if ($this->request->hasPost("message")) {
            $message = $this->request->getPost("message");
        } else {
            $message = " " ;
        }
 
        return ["message" => $message];
    }
}
```

LANGUAGE: php

```
++$j;
```

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
$intValue = (int) $input;
```

TITLE: Read Configuration with API - Python
DESCRIPTION: This Python snippet demonstrates how to use the `readConfig` endpoint to retrieve a specific part of the configuration (e.g., OPNsense.Firewall.Alias). It uses the `requests` library to make a GET request to the API, authenticating with a key and secret. The response contains the contents of the specified configuration path.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/api/be/OPNBEcore.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import json
import requests
auth = {
  "key":"3RhWOno+HwvtmT406I6zw8of8J6n9FOKlWK6U0B+K7stt/fDaJg7bjeF3QAshlScYqC+3o5THy3vQViW",
  "secret":"uaBk27NKhQCZSDpfAlG6YJ473MzvsCNiED6kzbYuykzU05fCRkcJADhDm5nxbZt8yREC74ZpvD/vbcEx"
}
r = requests.get(
    'https://127.0.0.1/api/opncentral/sync/read_config/OPNsense.Firewall.Alias',
    auth=(auth['key'], auth['secret']),
    verify=False    # use for localhost testing only
)
print(r.text)
```

TITLE: Basic Example of PSR-2 Compliance in PHP
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates basic PSR-2 compliance, including namespace declaration, use statements, class definition with inheritance and interfaces, method definition with visibility, and control structures with proper spacing and bracing.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr2.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php
namespace Vendor\Package;

use FooInterface;
use BarClass as Bar;
use OtherVendor\OtherPackage\BazClass;

class Foo extends Bar implements FooInterface
{
    public function sampleFunction($a, $b = null)
    {
        if ($a === $b) {
            bar();
        } elseif ($a > $b) {
            $foo->bar($arg1);
        } else {
            BazClass::bar($arg2, $arg3);
        }
    }

    final public static function bar()
    {
        // method body
    }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Standard API Response Format for Search Results (JSON)
DESCRIPTION: Shows the typical structure of the JSON response from a search-type OPNsense API endpoint. Returns metadata (total, rowCount, current) and an array of result rows, with each row containing service-specific fields (id, locked, running, description, name). Output is subject to endpoint-specific logic but generally follows this schema.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/api.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
    "total": 10,
    "rowCount": 7,
```

```
Phase 1 proposal (Algorithms)
-----------------------------

 **Lifetime**               28800 sec        *lifetime before renegotiation*
========================== ================ ============================================
```

TITLE: Defining XML Data Model with Array and Field Types
DESCRIPTION: Specifies the XML model for the GridExample module, defining a nested ArrayField named 'address' containing an enabled BooleanField and an email EmailField. This XML informs the OPNsense model loader about the data structure, validation requirements (e.g., required fields), and default values. The ArrayField type enables nested data with internal UUIDs for referencing, compatible with the PHP model class. This XML must be located alongside the PHP model for full integration.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/examples/using_grids.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: XML
CODE:
```
<model>
    <mount>//OPNsense/GridExample</mount>
    <description>
        the OPNsense "GridExample" application
    </description>
    <items>
        <addresses>
            <address type="ArrayField">
                <enabled type="BooleanField">
                    <default>1</default>
                    <Required>Y</Required>
                </enabled>
                <email type="EmailField">
                    <Required>Y</Required>
                </email>
            </address>
        </addresses>
    </items>
</model>

```

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```

```

TITLE: Configuring Serial Console Parameters at Boot Loader in OPNsense
DESCRIPTION: Shell commands to modify kernel parameters at the loader prompt when OPNsense hangs at 'booting...' on serial devices. These commands adjust UART flags, console speed, port settings, and console type to match the correct serial console configuration.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/troubleshooting/boot.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
set hint.uart.0.flags=0x0
set hint.uart.1.flags=0x10
set comconsole_speed=115200
set comconsole_port=0x2F8
set console=comconsole
boot
```

It uses the `set limits` directive to override default values for various test parameters like program output buffer size, file content buffer size, and various timeouts. Uncomment lines to activate specific limits.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/monit.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
## Set limits for various tests. The following example shows the default values:
##
set limits {
     programOutput:     5120 B,      # check program's output truncate limit
#     sendExpectBuffer:  256 B,      # limit for send/expect protocol test
     fileContentBuffer: 5120 B,      # limit for file content test
#     httpContentBuffer: 1 MB,       # limit for HTTP content test
#     networkTimeout:    5 seconds   # timeout for network I/O
#     programTimeout:    300 seconds # timeout for check program
#     stopTimeout:       30 seconds  # timeout for service stop
#     startTimeout:      120 seconds  # timeout for service start
#     restartTimeout:    30 seconds  # timeout for service restart
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Complex Routing with Caddy Handlers
DESCRIPTION: Example Caddyfile showing domain configurations with different routing handlers, including path-specific routing, access controls based on client IP, and multiple domain ports with different upstream targets.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/caddy.rst#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: caddyfile
CODE:
```
# Reverse Proxy Domain: "531e7877-0b58-4f93-a9f0-54beee58bdea"
opn.example.com:443 {
        handle /private/* {
                @d72c1182-6f05-4c25-8d9f-6a226a9039ea {
                        not client_ip 192.168.0.0/16 172.16.0.0/12 10.0.0.0/8
                }
                handle @d72c1182-6f05-4c25-8d9f-6a226a9039ea {
                        abort
                }

                reverse_proxy 172.16.99.10:8443 {
                }
        }

        handle /different_upstream/* {
                reverse_proxy 192.168.1.33 {
                }
        }

        handle {
                reverse_proxy 172.16.99.10:8443 {
                }
        }
}
# Reverse Proxy Domain: "58760ae1-2409-4a6b-a6c4-d58b15706b55"
opn.example.com:8443 {
        handle_path /strip_this {
                reverse_proxy 10.10.10.10:8443 {
                }
        }
}
```

TITLE: PHP Script for OPNsense Model Interaction
DESCRIPTION: This PHP script initializes necessary OPNsense/Phalcon components and demonstrates how to use a custom model. It loads the model from config, modifies data, adds a new item to a collection, performs validation, and saves the model back to config.xml if validation passes. Requires the `myVendorName\myModule\myModel` class and OPNsense core components.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/models_example.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: PHP
CODE:
```
<?php
// initialize phalcon components for our script
require_once("load_phalcon.php");

// include myModel and the shared config component
use myVendorName\myModule\myModel;
use OPNsense\Core\Config;

// create a new model, reading the model definition and the current data from our config.xml
$myMdl = new myModel();
$myMdl->exampleNumber =1;
$myMdl->contacts->someText = "just a test";

// add a new contact node
$node = $myMdl->contacts->entity->add();
$node->email = "test@test.com";
$node->name = "my test user";

// perform validation on the data in our model
$validationMessages = $myMdl->performValidation();
foreach ($validationMessages as  $messsage) {
    echo "validation failure on field ". $messsage->getField()."  returning message : ". $messsage->getMessage()."\n";
}

// if validation succeeded, write data back to config
if ($validationMessages->count() == 0) {
    // serialize our model to the config file (config.xml)
    // (this raises an error on validation failures)
    $myMdl->serializeToConfig();
    $cnf = Config::getInstance();
    $cnf->save();
}
```

TITLE: Implementing OPNsense Service API Controller (PHP)
DESCRIPTION: This PHP class defines the API controller for the 'helloworld' service, extending `ApiMutableServiceControllerBase` to provide standard service endpoints. It links the controller to the service model, configd template, configuration enabled flag, and the configd service name using static variables. The `reconfigureForceRestart` method is overridden to control restart behavior.

LANGUAGE: PHP
CODE:
```
use OPNsense\Base\ApiMutableServiceControllerBase;

class ServiceController extends ApiMutableServiceControllerBase
{
    protected static $internalServiceClass = '\OPNsense\HelloWorld\HelloWorld';
    protected static $internalServiceTemplate = 'OPNsense/HelloWorld';
    protected static $internalServiceEnabled = 'general.enabled';
    protected static $internalServiceName = 'helloworld';

    protected function reconfigureForceRestart()
    {
        return 0;
    }
}
```

TITLE: Creating Custom Model Migrations in OPNsense (PHP)
DESCRIPTION: Provides a boilerplate PHP class (`M1_0_0`) for implementing custom model migrations to a specific version (e.g., 1.0.0). The class extends `BaseModelMigration`, resides in the `Migrations` directory, and includes `run()` for pre-save logic (executed sequentially for each version step) and `post()` for post-sync actions. It's crucial to call `parent::run($model)` within the `run` method for standard migration steps.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/models_migrations.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
class M1_0_0 extends BaseModelMigration
{
    /**
     * default model migration
     * @param $model
     */
    public function run($model)
    {
        parent::run($model);
    }

    /**
     * post migration action, run after config sync
     * @param $model
     */
    public function post($model)
    {
        return;
```

TITLE: Form Data Type Formatting in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Implementation of a type formatter function that converts string values to integers for form data validation and proper JSON typing before sending to the server.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/view_js_helpers.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
function my_convert_to_int_function(payload)
{
    if (/^[+-]?[0-9]*$/.test(payload)) {
        return  parseInt(payload);
    } else {
        return payload;
    }
}
```

TITLE: Demonstrating Declarations Without Side Effects in PHP (PSR-1 Emulate)
DESCRIPTION: This PHP snippet provides an example of a file that adheres to the PSR-1 standard by containing only function declarations. It explicitly shows that conditional declarations (checking if a function exists before declaring it) are not considered side effects. This approach promotes code reusability and predictability when including files.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr1.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php
// declaration
function foo()
{
    // function body
}

// conditional declaration is *not* a side effect
if (! function_exists('bar')) {
    function bar()
    {
        // function body
    }
}

```

TITLE: Basic Plugin Service Registration in PHP
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to register a service in an OPNsense plugin by implementing the myplugin_services() function. This function returns an array with service details including name, description, and configd commands for start, stop, and restart operations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/backend/legacy.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: PHP
CODE:
```
function myplugin_services()
{
    $service = array();
    $service['name'] = 'myservice';
    $service['description'] = gettext('My service');
    $service['configd']['restart'] = array('myservice restart');
    $service['configd']['start'] = array('myservice start');
    $service['configd']['stop'] = array('myservice stop');
    $services[] = $pconfig;
    return $services;
}
```

```
}
```

TITLE: Disabling a firewall rule and managing savepoints in Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to disable a firewall rule and create a savepoint to allow reverting changes after 60 seconds if no rollback is invoked. It demonstrates dependency on specific firewall management functions and the use of savepoints to revert component-specific changes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/api/core/firewall.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
import firewall

# Disable a specific firewall rule
firewall.disable_rule(rule_id=42)

# Create a savepoint to be able to revert changes later
firewall.savepoint()

# If cancelRollback(savepoint) is not called within 60 seconds,
```

TITLE: Illustrating Side Effects and Declarations in PHP (PSR-1 Avoid)
DESCRIPTION: This PHP snippet demonstrates a file that includes both function declarations and direct side effects like changing INI settings, including other files, and generating output. According to PSR-1, files should ideally do one or the other, not both, to maintain clean separation and predictability.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr1.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php
// side effect: change ini settings
ini_set('error_reporting', E_ALL);

// side effect: loads a file
include "file.php";

// side effect: generates output
echo "<html>\n";

// declaration
function foo()
{
    // function body
}

```

TITLE: Adding an OPNsense Group via API with cURL
DESCRIPTION: Provides an example cURL command, often generated from browser developer tools, to add a new user group via the OPNsense API endpoint /api/auth/group/add/. It uses the POST method (`-X POST`), sets necessary headers (`-H 'accept: ...'`, `-H 'content-type: application/json'`), includes the group data in JSON format (`--data-raw`), and uses `--insecure` to bypass SSL certificate verification.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/how-tos/api.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
curl -X POST 'https://172.16.0.254:4444/api/auth/group/add/' \
-H 'accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01' \
-H 'content-type: application/json' \
--data-raw '{"group":{"name":"HelloWorld","description":"HelloWorld","priv":"page-system-login-logout","member":"0"}}' \
--insecure
```

TITLE: Verifying an unknown certificate using OCSP with OpenSSL
DESCRIPTION: This command uses OpenSSL to verify a certificate's status using the OCSP protocol. It queries a specified OCSP server to determine if a certificate is valid, revoked, or unknown. Requires the OCSP server to be running and accessible. Expects the CA certificate and serial number of the certificate to be verified. This command returns the status of the certificate (good, revoked, or unknown).
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/certificates.rst#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# openssl ocsp -url http://127.0.0.1:8081 -CAfile ca.crt -issuer ca.crt -serial 9999
Response verify OK
9999: unknown
        This Update: Jan  6 13:36:51 2024 GMT
```

TITLE: Fixing Package Manager Issues via Command Line (OPNsense)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides command-line instructions to address common package manager errors encountered during OPNsense upgrades. Specifically, it covers issues related to a lost package manager database and a broken installation, offering solutions using `opnsense-bootstrap` and package reinstallation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/updates.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
* "Could not determine core package name." can indicate that the local package manager database was lost. See `opnsense-bootstrap` command to fix.
* "No package manager is installed to perform upgrades." can indicate a broken installation. Try to reinstall the "pkg" package via `System --> Firmware --> Packages`.
* "The Package manager is incompatible and needs a reinstall." can indicate misuse of the FreeBSD repository. Try to reinstall the "pkg" package via `System --> Firmware --> Packages`.
* "Core package not known to package database." can mean that the mirror settings are wrong, the main mirror no longer holds any packages or that the mirror is unreachable for other reasons.
```

TITLE: Initializing and Rendering OPNsense Templates Using Python
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to programmatically use the OPNsense template system module independently of the configd daemon. The example imports template and config modules, initializes a Template object with a target root directory, loads a configuration XML file, binds the loaded config to the template, and generates output files for the 'OPNsense/Sample' package. Finally, it iterates and prints the generated filenames. Required dependencies include the 'modules.template' and 'modules.config' Python modules and access to a valid /config.xml file.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/backend/templates.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# import template system and config.xml handling
from modules import template
from modules import config
 
# construct a new template object, set root to /tmp/
tmpl = template.Template(target_root_directory='/tmp/')
# open the config.xml and bind to template object
conf = config.Config('/config.xml')
tmpl.set_config(conf.get())
 
# generate output for OPNsense/Sample
generated_filenames = tmpl.generate('OPNsense/Sample')
 
# print results
for filename in generated_filenames:
  print ('.. generated : %s'%filename)
```

TITLE: Verifying OPNsense Installation Image Signature Using OpenSSL - Shell
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the process of verifying the integrity and authenticity of the OPNsense installation image using OpenSSL commands. It requires previously downloaded files: a SHA-256 checksum file, the compressed image file, a signature file, and the OpenSSL public key. The commands include checking the SHA-256 checksum of the compressed image and verifying the signature against the public key after decoding the signature from base64 format. This ensures the image has not been tampered with before installation. It is important to decompress the image file using 'bunzip2' before performing signature verification, as signatures are generated prior to compression. Inputs are the specific filenames matching the downloaded files, and output is a confirmation of verification or an error indication.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/install.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
openssl sha256 OPNsense-<filename>.bz2

openssl base64 -d -in OPNsense-<filename>.<image>.sig -out /tmp/image.sig
openssl dgst -sha256 -verify OPNsense-<filename>.pub -signature /tmp/image.sig OPNsense-<filename>.<image>
```

TITLE: Sampling Kernel Stacks for Flame Graph with DTrace (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: Uses `dtrace` to sample kernel stacks system-wide (`profile-997`) at 997 Hz for 60 seconds (`tick-60s`). `-x stackframes=100` limits stack depth, `/arg0/` ensures it applies only when a kernel stack is available, and `@ [stack()] = count();` aggregates counts of unique stacks. The output is saved to `out.kern_stacks`, suitable for Flame Graph generation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/how-tos/dtrace.rst#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
# dtrace -x stackframes=100 -n 'profile-997 /arg0/ { @[stack()] = count(); } tick-60s { exit(0); }' -o out.kern_stacks
```

TITLE: Configuring IPsec Parameters for VPN Connection in Windows PowerShell
DESCRIPTION: This snippet uses Set-VpnConnectionIPsecConfiguration to specify IPsec encryption and integrity algorithms, Diffie-Hellman and PFS groups, and associates them with the existing VPN connection. It enforces AES256 for encryption, SHA256 for integrity, and Group14 (modp2048) for DH and PFS, matching the OPNsense proposals. Parameters must mirror server-side settings for successful connections. Used after creating the VPN connection; requires administrative permissions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-swanctl-rw-ikev2-eap-mschapv2.rst#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: PowerShell
CODE:
```
Set-VpnConnectionIPsecConfiguration -ConnectionName "vpn1.example.com" -AuthenticationTransformConstants SHA256 -CipherTransformConstants AES256 -EncryptionMethod AES256 -IntegrityCheckMethod SHA256 -PfsGroup PFS2048 -DHGroup Group14 -PassThru -Force
```

TITLE: Formatting switch/case Structures - PHP
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the recommended coding style for switch statements. It shows indentation rules for `case` and terminal keywords (`break`, `return`), brace placement, and the use of `// no break` to indicate intentional fall-through.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr2.rst#_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php
switch ($expr) {
    case 0:
        echo 'First case, with a break';
        break;
    case 1:
        echo 'Second case, which falls through';
        // no break
    case 2:
    case 3:
    case 4:
        echo 'Third case, return instead of break';
        return;
    default:
        echo 'Default case';
        break;
}
```

TITLE: Registering Virtual Interfaces in PHP
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to implement the myplugin_interfaces() function to register virtual network interfaces. This example creates a TUN interface with specific properties when the plugin is enabled in the configuration.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/backend/legacy.rst#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: PHP
CODE:
```
function myplugin_interfaces()
{
    global $config;

    $interfaces = array();
    if (isset($config['myplugin']['enable'])) {
        $oic = array("enable" => true);
        $oic['if'] = 'tun0';
        $oic['descr'] = 'myplugin';
        $oic['type'] = "none";
        $oic['virtual'] = true;
        $oic['networks'] = array();
        $interfaces['tun0'] = $oic;
    }

    return $interfaces;
}
```

It specifies the upstream protocol (HTTP or HTTPS), the target IP address or hostname (`192.168.10.1`), and the target port (`80`). Optionally allows skipping TLS certificate verification for HTTPS upstreams in private networks.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/caddy.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: Text
CODE:
```
============================== ======================================================================
Options                        Values
============================== ======================================================================
*Frontend*
**Domain:**                    ``https://foo.example.com``
*Upstream*
**Protocol:**                  ``http://`` or ``https://`` - depending on your upstream webserver
**Upstream Domain:**           ``192.168.10.1``
**Upstream Port:**             ``80`` - `or set the port required by your upstream webserver`
**TLS Insecure Skip Verify**   ``X`` - `if https:// was chosen`
============================== ======================================================================
```

TITLE: Communicating with Cellular Modem via AT Commands in FreeBSD Shell
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to open a call-out port to a cellular modem device using the cu command on FreeBSD, enabling manual interaction with AT commands to verify modem function. Required dependencies include the cu utility (part of the base FreeBSD system). Replace /dev/cuaU0.2 with your actual modem device file. Once connected, typing 'AT' should yield 'OK' if the modem is responsive. To exit cu, type '~.'. The expected output for a healthy modem connection is an 'OK' response. Limitations: Device file names may differ per hardware; if no 'OK', try other device files.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/cellular.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: Shell
CODE:
```
cu -l /dev/cuaU0.2
Connected
AT (<-type that)
OK
```

TITLE: Configuring Phase 2 Settings for IPsec VPN with IKEv2
DESCRIPTION: This snippet explains setting up Phase 2 parameters such as tunnel mode, local network, encryption, hash algorithms, PFS support, and lifetime. It also covers enabling the setup and advises on restarting the service to apply configuration changes properly.

```
Step 3 - Phase 2 Mobile Clients
-------------------------------
Press the *+* button to add a new Phase 2 entry.

General information
-------------------
================= =============== ==============================
 **Mode**          Tunnel IPv4     *Select Tunnel mode*
 **Description**   MobileIPsecP2   *Freely chosen description*
================= =============== ==============================

Local Network
--------------
=================== ============ ==============================
 **Local Network**   LAN subnet     *Route the local LAN subnet*
=================== ============ ==============================

Phase 2 proposal (SA/Key Exchange)
----------------------------------
=========================== ============== ====================================================
 **Protocol**                ESP            *Choose ESP for encryption*
 **Encryption algorithms**   AES / 256      *For this example we use AES 256*
 **Hash algorithms**         SHA1, SHA256   *Same as before, mix SHA1 and SHA256*
 **PFS Key group**           off            *Most mobile systems do not support PFS in Phase2*
 **Lifetime**                3600 sec
=========================== ============== ====================================================

Save settings, enable IPsec, and restart service if needed for proper application.
```

TITLE: Using switch Control Structure in PHP
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the usage of the switch statement for multiple case conditions including breaks, fallthrough without breaks, and returning from a case block. The example highlights control flow with case and default clauses. No external dependencies are required. The switch expression can span multiple lines under defined indentation and formatting rules.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
switch ($expr) {
    case 0:
        echo 'First case, with a break';
        break;
    case 1:
        echo 'Second case, which falls through';
        // no break
    case 2:
    case 3:
    case 4:
        echo 'Third case, return instead of break';
        return;
    default:
        echo 'Default case';
        break;
}
```

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

switch (
    $expr1
    && $expr2
) {
    // structure body
}
```

TITLE: Declaring Closures with Arguments and Use Variables in PHP
DESCRIPTION: Examples of closure declarations with arguments, captured variables (using the use keyword), and optional return type declarations. The snippets demonstrate proper spacing around keywords, parentheses, commas, and braces. Also includes multi-line argument and use lists adhering to indentation and line break rules, and usage of closures as function/method arguments.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_26

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

$closureWithArgs = function ($arg1, $arg2) {
    // body
};

$closureWithArgsAndVars = function ($arg1, $arg2) use ($var1, $var2) {
    // body
};

$closureWithArgsVarsAndReturn = function ($arg1, $arg2) use ($var1, $var2): bool {
    // body
};
```

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

$longArgs_noVars = function (
    $longArgument,
    $longerArgument,
    $muchLongerArgument
) {
   // body
};

$noArgs_longVars = function () use (
    $longVar1,
    $longerVar2,
    $muchLongerVar3
) {
   // body
};

$longArgs_longVars = function (
    $longArgument,
    $longerArgument,
    $muchLongerArgument
) use (
    $longVar1,
    $longerVar2,
    $muchLongerVar3
) {
   // body
};

$longArgs_shortVars = function (
    $longArgument,
    $longerArgument,
    $muchLongerArgument
) use ($var1) {
   // body
};

$shortArgs_longVars = function ($arg) use (
    $longVar1,
    $longerVar2,
    $muchLongerVar3
) {
   // body
};
```

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

$foo->bar(
    $arg1,
    function ($arg2) use ($var1) {
        // body
    },
    $arg3
);
```

TITLE: jQuery API integration
DESCRIPTION: This HTML/JavaScript snippet integrates the HelloWorld module's form with the API using jQuery. It uses 'mapDataToFormUI' to load data from the '/api/helloworld/settings/get' endpoint into the form, and 'saveFormToEndpoint' to save the form data to the '/api/helloworld/settings/set' endpoint. It also includes a call to reload the service after a successful save using 'ajaxCall'.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/examples/helloworld.rst#_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
    <script type="text/javascript">
        $( document ).ready(function() {
            mapDataToFormUI({'frm_GeneralSettings':'/api/helloworld/settings/get'}).done(function(data){
                // place actions to run after load, for example update form styles.
            });

            // link save button to API set action
            $("#saveAct").click(function(){
                saveFormToEndpoint("/api/helloworld/settings/set",'frm_GeneralSettings',function(){
                    // action to run after successful save, for example reconfigure service.
                    ajaxCall(url="/api/helloworld/service/reload", sendData={},callback=function(data,status) {
                        // action to run after reload
                    });
                });
            });
        });
    </script>
     
    <div class="col-md-12">
        <button class="btn btn-primary"  id="saveAct" type="button"><b>{{ lang._('Save') }}</b></button>
    </div>
```

TITLE: Example On Markup Rendered - JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to use the onMarkupRendered function to make an API call and process the returned data. The ajaxCall function is awaited to ensure the widget remains responsive.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/dashboard.rst#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
async onMarkupRendered() {
    await this.ajaxCall('/api/interfaces/overview/interfacesInfo', {}, (data, status) => {
        // do something with the data
    });
```

TITLE: CSV Import Method in OPNsense API Controller

SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/controller.rst#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
public function uploadReservationsAction()
{
    if ($this->request->isPost() && $this->request->hasPost('payload')) {
        return $this->importCsv(
            'path.to.items',
            $this->request->getPost('payload'),
            ['my_key']
        );
    }
}
```

```
}
```

TITLE: Verifying OPNsense Image Signatures Using OpenSSL in Shell
DESCRIPTION: This shell snippet demonstrates how to verify the signature of a compressed OPNsense image file using OpenSSL. It decodes the base64 signature file, then uses the decoded signature along with the public key to verify the SHA-256 digest of the image. The commands must be run in a Unix shell environment with OpenSSL installed, requiring the base64 signature file, image file, and public key file. The output confirms the authenticity of the image based on the provided signature and public key.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/releases/CE_18.7.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# openssl base64 -d -in image.bz2.sig -out /tmp/image.sig
# openssl dgst -sha256 -verify rsa.pub -signature /tmp/image.sig image.bz2
```

```
}
```

TITLE: Example On Widget Resize - JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to adjust the visibility and styling of elements within the widget based on its width. If the width is less than 500px, less critical information is hidden.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/dashboard.rst#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
onWidgetResize(elem, width, height) {
    if (width > 500) {
        $('.interface-info-detail').parent().show();
        $('.interface-info').css('justify-content', 'initial');
        $('.interface-info').css('text-align', 'left');
    } else {
        $('.interface-info-detail').parent().hide();
        $('.interface-info').css('justify-content', 'center');
        $('.interface-info').css('text-align', 'center');
    }
}
```

TITLE: DependConstraint Example in XML
DESCRIPTION: This XML snippet demonstrates how to use the DependConstraint to link the validation of `sslurlonly` to the `sslbump` option.  When either `sslbump` or `sslurlonly` changes, both fields are re-validated. The `<reference>` tag is key to ensuring bi-directional validation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/models_constraints.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: xml
CODE:
```
<sslbump type="BooleanField">
    <Constraints>
        <check001>
            <type>DependConstraint</type>
            <addFields>
                <field1>sslurlonly</field1>
            </addFields>
        </check001>
    </Constraints>
</sslbump>
<sslurlonly type="BooleanField">
    <Constraints>
        <check001>
            <reference>sslbump.check001</reference>
        </check001>
    </Constraints>
</sslurlonly>
```

TITLE: Adding Firewall Rule - OPNsense IPsec to Internet IPv6 - Configuration
DESCRIPTION: Creates an IPsec firewall rule allowing any IPv6 traffic from the roadwarrior network alias (`net_pool_roadwarrior`) to destinations *not* matching the `InternetIPv6` alias (effectively allowing access to the internet). This rule facilitates full tunnel IPv6 access for roadwarriors and requires the destination alias to be configured correctly.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-swanctl-rw-ikev2-eap-mschapv2.rst#_snippet_17

LANGUAGE: OPNsense Configuration
CODE:
```
    ==============================================  ====================================================================================================
    **Action**                                      Pass
    **Interface**                                   IPsec
    **Direction**                                   In
    **TCP/IP Version**                              IPv6
    **Protocol**                                    Any
    **Source**                                      ``net_pool_roadwarrior``
    **Source port**                                 Any
    **Destination / Invert**                        X
    **Destination**                                 ``InternetIPv6``
    **Destination port**                            Any
    **Description**                                 Allow Internet Access IPv6
    ==============================================  ====================================================================================================
```

TITLE: Visually Diagramming OPNsense Bandwidth Shaping Topology - nwdiag
DESCRIPTION: This nwdiag snippet visualizes the layout of a network with OPNsense acting as a firewall shaping bandwidth between a LAN and the internet. Dependencies include nwdiag and a Sphinx-compatible diagram plugin. The diagram includes cloud/internet, a switch, OPNsense firewall (fw1) on both LAN and WAN sides, and labels IP ranges. The diagram aids administrators in understanding traffic paths but is not executable code.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/shaper_share_evenly.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: nwdiag
CODE:
```
nwdiag {

  span_width = 90;
  node_width = 180;
  Internet [shape = "cisco.cloud"];
  pc [label="Connected PC's",shape="cisco.pc"];
  pc -- switchlan;

  network LAN {
    switchlan [label="",shape = "cisco.workgroup_switch"];
    label = "LAN OPNsense";
    address ="192.168.1.x/24";
    fw1 [label="OPNsense",address="192.168.1.1/24"];
  }

  network WAN  {
    label = ".WAN OPNsense";
    fw1 [label="OPNsense", shape = "cisco.firewall", address="172.10.1.1/32"];
    Internet;
  }

}
```

TITLE: XML Example for InterfaceField with Filters
DESCRIPTION: Defines an XML structure for an InterfaceField with multiple, required, default settings, and regex filters for enable and IP address validation. This snippet establishes how interface settings are specified and validated using regex filters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/models_fieldtypes.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: xml
CODE:
```
<interfaces type="InterfaceField">
    <Required>Y</Required>
    <multiple>Y</multiple>
    <default>lan</default>
    <filters>
        <enable>/^(?!0).*$/</enable>
        <ipaddr>/^((?!dhcp).)*$/</ipaddr>
    </filters>
</interfaces>
```

TITLE: Setting net.isr.bindthreads and net.isr.maxthreads
DESCRIPTION: These sysctl settings configure the netisr subsystem to improve packet dispatching across multiple CPU cores when using RSS. `net.isr.bindthreads=1` binds threads to specific CPUs, while `net.isr.maxthreads=-1` assigns a workstream to each available core, thus optimizing for multi-core processing. They are set through the system settings menu.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/troubleshooting/performance.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
net.isr.bindthreads = 1
net.isr.maxthreads = -1
```

TITLE: Registering Syslog Targets in PHP for OPNsense
DESCRIPTION: This code defines a function to register syslog targets within OPNsense by returning an array with facility groups. The function creates an associative array mapping application identifiers to their syslog facility configurations. Dependencies include PHP arrays, and the function should return correctly structured data for syslog integration. Used for monitoring and remote logging configuration.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/backend/legacy.rst#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: PHP
CODE:
```
function myplugin_syslog()
{
    $logfacilities = array();
    $logfacilities['myplugin'] = array(
        'facility' => array('myplugin'),
    );
    return $logfacilities;
}
```

TITLE: Formatting Multi-Line Closure Arguments/Vars - PHP
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to format closures when argument or variable lists are split across multiple lines. It shows indentation, one item per line, and the specific placement of the closing parenthesis and opening brace on a new line when the last list is multi-line.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr2.rst#_snippet_19

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php
$longArgs_noVars = function (
    $longArgument,
    $longerArgument,
    $muchLongerArgument
) {
   // body
};

$noArgs_longVars = function () use (
    $longVar1,
    $longerVar2,
    $muchLongerVar3
) {
   // body
};

$longArgs_longVars = function (
    $longArgument,
    $longerArgument,
    $muchLongerArgument
) use (
    $longVar1,
    $longerVar2,
    $muchLongerVar3
) {
   // body
};

$longArgs_shortVars = function (
    $longArgument,
    $longerArgument,
    $muchLongerArgument
) use ($var1) {
   // body
};

$shortArgs_longVars = function ($arg) use (
    $longVar1,
    $longerVar2,
    $muchLongerVar3
) {
   // body
};
```

TITLE: Checking Page Accessibility Using OPNsense ACL in PHP
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to utilize the OPNsense ACL system from PHP code to verify if a given user has access to a specified page URI. Dependencies include the OPNsense\Core\ACL class. This snippet illustrates straightforward runtime permission checking leveraging stored privilege configurations and ACL XML definitions.

```
}
```

TITLE: Registering ET Pro Telemetry Token
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides instructions on registering the ET Pro Telemetry token within the OPNsense Intrusion Detection system. It involves navigating to the Administration section, accessing the Download tab, enabling the desired categories, pasting the received token, saving the configuration, and initiating a ruleset update. The token is obtained after registration and is essential for activating the ET Pro ruleset.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/etpro_telemetry.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
1.  Go to :menuselection:`Services --> Intrusion Detection --> Administration`
2.  Click on the "Download" tab, which should show you a list of available rules.
3.  Enable all categories you would like to monitor in the "ET telemetry" section,
    if in doubt enable all and monitor the alerts later (select on the right and use the enable selected button on top)
4.  At the bottom of the page there’s a block containing settings, paste the token code you received via email in **et_telemetry.token**
5.  Press **save** to persist your token code
6.  Press **Download & Update rules** to fetch the current ruleset
```

TITLE: Implementing Searchable Recordsets in OPNsense API Controller
DESCRIPTION: Example of using searchRecordsetBase() method to implement searchable recordsets without a model. This approach is useful for legacy data or system statistics that don't have a formal model.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/controller.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
class TestController extends ApiControllerBase
{
    /**
     * @return array
     */
    public function searchAction()
    {
        $records = [];
        $records[] = ['id' => '1', 'description' => 'test 1'];
        $records[] = ['id' => '2', 'description' => 'test 2'];
        $records[] = ['id' => '3', 'description' => 'test 3'];
        return $this->searchRecordsetBase($records);
    }
}
```

TITLE: Verifying a revoked certificate with OpenSSL
DESCRIPTION: This command uses OpenSSL to verify a certificate against the provided CA chain and CRL.  It checks if the certificate has been revoked. Requires openssl to be installed. Expects files named my_chain.pem and revoked_cert.crt to be available in the current directory.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/certificates.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# openssl verify -crl_check -CAfile my_chain.pem revoked_cert.crt
C=NL, CN=my_cert
error 23 at 0 depth lookup: certificate revoked
error ocsp_user_cert2.crt: verification failed
```

TITLE: Configuring Mobile Clients in OPNsense IPsec VPN
DESCRIPTION: This snippet describes setting up mobile clients' network and authentication source within OPNsense's IPsec VPN configuration. It details the interface selection, authentication mode, IP pool range, and the process of saving and initiating Phase 1 for mobile client VPNs.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-rw-srv-eaptls.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
Go to :menuselection:`VPN --> IPsec --> Mobile Clients`

Set the following options:

IKE Extensions
--------------
========================== ================ =============================================
 **Enable**                 checked          *check to enable mobile clients*
 **User Authentication**    Local Database   *For the example we use the Local Database*
 **Group Authentication**   none             *Leave on none*
 **Virtual Address Pool**   10.10.0.0/24     *Enter the IP range for the remote clients*
========================== ================ =============================================

Save settings and select **Create Phase1**.
```

TITLE: Using Policy Tester JSON Output in OPNProxy Plugin - JSON
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows a JSON example output from the OPNProxy ACL tester feature, which is used to debug and verify access control rules. It includes details about the decision made by the proxy such as the matching policy's properties, the user information including groups, and the specific deny action triggered. This output helps administrators understand how a URL request by a given user is handled by the access control policies. The snippet assumes the user submits a username and URL for testing via the plugin's UI and the response is returned in this structured JSON format.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/opnproxy.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
```
{
  "message": "ERR message=\"reason:c1380754-e14b-4dc7-bcf9-96307450c025 policy_type:custom\" user=\"root\"\n",
  "user": {
    "uid": "root",
    "id": "0",
    "applies_on": [
      "u:root",
      "g:admins"
    ]
  },
  "policy": {
    "action": "deny",
    "id": "c1380754-e14b-4dc7-bcf9-96307450c025",
    "applies_on": [
      "g:admins"
    ],
    "policy_type": "custom",
    "description": "test_custom2",
    "path": "/",
    "wildcard": true,
    "domain": "google.nl"
  }
}
```

TITLE: Declaring Class Properties with Visibility and Type Hints (PHP)
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the standard declaration format for PHP class properties. Visibility (e.g., `public`) MUST be declared, the `var` keyword MUST NOT be used, only one property should be declared per statement, and there MUST be a space between the type declaration (if present) and the property name. Static properties are also shown.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

namespace Vendor\Package;

class ClassName
{
    public $foo = null;
    public static int $bar = 0;
}
```

DESCRIPTION: This Makefile defines essential metadata for the 'helloworld' OPNsense plugin, including its name (PLUGIN_NAME), version (PLUGIN_VERSION), a brief description (PLUGIN_COMMENT), and the maintainer's contact information (PLUGIN_MAINTAINER). It includes the standard OPNsense plugin makefile (`../../Mk/plugins.mk`) to leverage the common build infrastructure.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/examples/helloworld.rst#_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: kconfig

TITLE: Defining ACL Structure in XML Format
DESCRIPTION: Defines the structure and format of ACL files used in OPNsense to associate unique ACL keys with human-readable names and lists of URI patterns that specify accessible paths. The XML format must be stored in a specific model location and follows a strict schema to ensure compatibility with the ACL system. This snippet shows how to define an ACL entry with a key, name, and URI patterns.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/components/acl.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<acl>
  <my-unique-acl-key>             <!-- as stored for the user/group -->
     <name>My ACL name</name>     <!-- name visible in the user manager -->
     <patterns>
        <pattern>path/to/my/module</pattern>      <!-- list of uri's this ACL should unlock. -->
     </patterns>
  </my-unique-acl-key>
</acL>
```

TITLE: Create Presentation XML
DESCRIPTION: This XML snippet defines the presentation layer for the HelloWorld module's general settings form. It specifies the fields to be displayed, their labels, types (e.g., checkbox, text), and help text. The 'id' attribute maps the field to the data model. This XML drives the form rendering in the user interface.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/examples/helloworld.rst#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: xml
CODE:
```
    <form>
        <field>
            <id>helloworld.general.Enabled</id>
            <label>enabled</label>
            <type>checkbox</type>
            <help>Enable this feature</help>
        </field>
        <field>
            <id>helloworld.general.SMTPHost</id>
            <label>SMTPHost</label>
            <type>text</type>
            <help><![CDATA[ip address of the mail host]]></help>
            <hint>choose a valid IPv4/v6 address</hint>
        </field>
        <field>
            <id>helloworld.general.FromEmail</id>
            <label>Email (from)</label>
            <type>text</type>
        </field>
        <field>
            <id>helloworld.general.ToEmail</id>
            <label>Email (to)</label>
            <type>text</type>
        </field>
        <field>
            <id>helloworld.general.Description</id>
            <label>Description</label>
            <type>text</type>
        </field>
     </form>
```

TITLE: Formatting Nullable Type Declarations (PHP)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the formatting for nullable type declarations in PHP function/method arguments and return types, using `declare(strict_types=1)`. There MUST NOT be a space between the question mark (`?`) and the type name (e.g., `?string`).
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

declare(strict_types=1);

namespace Vendor\Package;

class ReturnTypeVariations
{
    public function functionName(?string $arg1, ?int &$arg2): ?string
    {
        return 'foo';
    }
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Stunnel Client for OPNsense Connection
DESCRIPTION: Stunnel client configuration that connects to an OPNsense server. This configuration establishes a secure tunnel for proxy traffic, requiring certificate-based authentication with certificate chain verification.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/stunnel.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: ini
CODE:
```
[proxy]
client = yes
accept = 127.0.0.1:3128
connect = our.opnsense.address:31280
requireCert = yes
verifyChain = yes
cert = /path/to/client.pem
CAfile = /path/to/ca.pem
```

TITLE: Configuring GENERIC for DTrace Kernel Build (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: Adds necessary options to the `/usr/src/sys/[ARCH]/conf/GENERIC` file to enable DTrace support in the OPNsense kernel build. `DEBUG=-g` enables debug symbols, `WITH_CTF=1` adds CTF type data, and `options KDTRACE_FRAME` ensures frame pointers are included. These are prerequisites for building a kernel with DTrace capabilities.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/how-tos/dtrace.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
makeoptions 	DEBUG=-g 		# Will build a debug kernel (using gdb debug symbols)
makeoptions 	WITH_CTF=1 		# Adds CTF type data to built executables
options		KDTRACE_FRAME 		# Ensure frames are compiled in
```

TITLE: Generating SSH Key Pair Using ssh-keygen in Shell
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to generate a new SSH key pair using the ssh-keygen tool with the ed25519 algorithm for use in SFTP-based OPNsense backups. The -C flag specifies a descriptive comment such as the user’s email address, and the -f flag sets the filename for the output keys. The private key (my_new_key) is stored securely, and the public key (my_new_key.pub) is added to the authorized_keys file on the target backup host. No passphrase is set to enable automated backup processes. Dependencies: OpenSSH must be installed on both the OPNsense system and the backup server.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/sftp-backup.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com" -f my_new_key
```

```
    ==============================================  ====================================================================================================

    **Protocol**                                    any
    **Source**                                      ``net_pool_roadwarrior``
    **Source port**                                 any
    **Destination**                                 any
    **Destination port**                            any
    **Translation / target**                        ``WAN address``
    **Description**                                 IPsec MASQ
    ==============================================  ====================================================================================================
```

TITLE: Managing VPN Connection Routes with PowerShell
DESCRIPTION: This snippet includes commands for adding IPv4 and IPv6 routes to the VPN connection, retrieving current routes, and removing routes if needed. 'Add-VpnConnectionRoute' attaches a specific network prefix to the VPN and is necessary when split tunneling is enabled. These commands require the VPN connection to be preconfigured and the use of proper prefixes matching internal networks. Outputs include updated route tables associated with the VPN connection.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-swanctl-rw-ikev2-eap-mschapv2.rst#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: PowerShell
CODE:
```
# Add IPv4 route
Add-VpnConnectionRoute -ConnectionName 'vpn1.example.com' -DestinationPrefix '192.168.1.0/24' -PassThru
```

LANGUAGE: PowerShell
CODE:
```
# Add IPv6 route
Add-VpnConnectionRoute -ConnectionName 'vpn1.example.com' -DestinationPrefix 'fe0d:abcd:1234:cafe::/64' -PassThru
```

LANGUAGE: PowerShell
CODE:
```
# Get corresponding route with VPN connection
(Get-VpnConnection -ConnectionName 'vpn1.example.com').routes
```

TITLE: Converting Legacy IPsec Tunnel Configuration from swanctl.conf to OPNsense GUI
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to manually migrate a legacy IPsec tunnel configuration from a swanctl.conf file to the OPNsense GUI, including detailed parameter mappings and configuration steps. It enables users to transition legacy setups to the modern connection-based configuration system.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/vpnet.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: none
CODE:
```
# This file is automatically generated. Do not edit
connections {
    con1 {
        unique = replace
        aggressive = no
        version = 2
        mobike = yes
        local_addrs = 203.0.113.1
        local-0 {
            id = 203.0.113.1
            auth = psk
        }
        remote-0 {
            id = 198.51.100.1
            auth = psk
        }
        encap = no
        remote_addrs = 198.51.100.1
        proposals = aes256-sha256-modp2048
        children {
            con1 {
                start_action = start
                policies = yes
                mode = tunnel
                sha256_96 = no
                local_ts = 192.168.1.0/24
                remote_ts = 172.16.100.0/24
                reqid = 1
                esp_proposals = aes256-sha256-modp2048
            }
        }
    }
}
parks {
}
secrets {
    ike-p1-0 {
        id-0 = 198.51.100.1
        secret = 0saGVsbG93b3JsZA==
    }
}
```

TITLE: Forward Auth Configuration with Authelia
DESCRIPTION: Caddyfile configuration example showing how to implement forward authentication with Authelia. The setup delegates authentication to Authelia before proxying requests to the backend application.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/caddy.rst#_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: caddyfile
CODE:
```
app1.example.com {
    handle {
        forward_auth authelia:9091 {
            uri /api/verify?rd=https://auth.example.com
            copy_headers Remote-User Remote-Groups Remote-Name Remote-Email
        }
        reverse_proxy 192.168.10.1:8080 {
        }
    }
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Shared IPv6 Pool for IPsec Roadwarriors
DESCRIPTION: Defines an IPv6 address pool named 'pool-roadwarrior-ipv6' within the OPNsense IPsec settings. Roadwarriors connecting via Method 1 (shared pool) will be assigned an IP address from the '2001:db8:1234:ec::/120' range (providing 256 addresses). It also configures the IPv6 DNS server '2001:db8:1234:1::1' to be pushed to clients. This configuration is optional if IPv6 is not used.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-swanctl-rw-ikev2-eap-mschapv2.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: Configuration
CODE:
```
Name: pool-roadwarrior-ipv6
Network: 2001:db8:1234:ec::/120
DNS: 2001:db8:1234:1::1
```

TITLE: Configuring OPNsense Ndproxy Service Settings
DESCRIPTION: Outlines the settings required to enable and configure the `ndproxy` service for relaying Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) messages between Uplink (WAN) and Downlink interfaces. Requires enabling the service, specifying interfaces, the CPE router's WAN MAC address, and the PE router's link-local address. The Uplink interface must be set to promiscuous mode.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/ndproxy.rst#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: Configuration
CODE:
```
**Enable**                                      ``X``
**Uplink Interface**                            ``WAN``
                                                (Interface must be in promiscuous mode)
**Downlink MAC Address**                        ``aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff``
                                                (MAC address of the CPE router's WAN interface)
**Uplink IPv6 Addresses**                       ``fe80::1``
                                                (Link-local address of the PE router's WAN interface)
**Exception IPv6 Addresses**                    `leave empty`
```

TITLE: Setting OPNsense DHCP Client Send Options for Sky UK
DESCRIPTION: Specifies the combined string for the 'Send Options' field within the OPNsense WAN interface DHCP Client Configuration (Advanced settings). This string includes the 'dhcp-client-identifier' (Option 61) with placeholder credentials and the 'dhcp-class-identifier' (Option 60), which are necessary for establishing a connection with Sky UK's VDSL network. The user ID and password in Option 61 can be arbitrary but must follow the specified format; the Option 60 value may or may not be strictly required but is included for completeness.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/SkyUK.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: configuration
CODE:
```
dhcp-client-identifier \"12345678@skydsl|12345678\",dhcp-class-identifier \"7.16a4N_UNI|PCBAFAST2504Nv1.0\"
```

TITLE: Configuring EAP Pre-Shared Key for IPsec User
DESCRIPTION: Creates an EAP Pre-Shared Key entry in OPNsense IPsec settings for user authentication. The 'Local Identifier' serves as the username (e.g., 'john@vpn1.example.com'), and the 'Pre-Shared Key' is the user's password. The 'Remote Identifier' can optionally specify the server FQDN, which may be required by some clients like the native Android client.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-swanctl-rw-ikev2-eap-mschapv2.rst#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: Configuration
CODE:
```
Local Identifier: john@vpn1.example.com
Remote Identifier: vpn1.example.com (optional, needed for native android client, if it causes issues remove it)
Pre-Shared Key: 48o72g3h4ro8123g8r
Type: EAP
```

TITLE: Network Topology Diagram for IPsec VTI Setup
DESCRIPTION: A network diagram representation showing the topology of two sites (A and B) connected via IPsec VTI. Site A has network 10.2.0.0/24, Site B has 192.168.2.0/24, and they're connected through a transit network 10.10.1.0/24 with tunnel addresses 192.168.123.1 and 192.168.123.2.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-s2s-conn-route.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: plaintext
CODE:
```
nwdiag {

  span_width = 90;
  node_width = 180;
  network A {
      address = "10.2.0.0/24";
      pclana [label="PC Site A\n10.2.0.20",shape="cisco.pc"];
      fwa [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="10.2.0.1/24"];
  }
  network Ext {
      address = "10.10.1.0/24";
      label = "Ext-VTI\n192.168.123.1 <--> 192.168.123.2";
      fwa [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="10.10.1.1/24"];
      fwb [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="10.10.1.2/24"];
  }
  network B {
      address = "192.168.2.0/24"
      fwb [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="192.168.2.20"];
      pclanb [label="PC Site B\n192.168.2.20",shape="cisco.pc"];
  }


}
```
