TITLE: Diagramming Alias Merging in OPNcentral Provisioning
DESCRIPTION: A blockdiag definition illustrating how local and central firewall aliases can be merged during OPNcentral provisioning. LANGUAGE: blockdiag
CODE:

```
blockdiag {
   local_alias_1 [label="'local'\nlocal_alias_1"];
   central_alias_1 [label="'central'\ncentral_alias_1"];
   local_alias_2 [label="'merged'\nlocal_alias_2"];
   local_alias_1 -> local_alias_2 [label="in"]
   central_alias_1 -> local_alias_2 [label="in"];
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Floating Rule for Inter/Intra-Zone ICMP in OPNsense
DESCRIPTION: Defines a floating firewall rule (Firewall -> Rules -> Floating) allowing ICMP traffic between and within the TRUST, UNTRUST, and WIFI zones. This rule uses the automatically generated network aliases (`TRUST net`, `UNTRUST net`, `WIFI net`) for source and destination, applies to any interface for inbound IPv4 traffic, and uses 'Quick' to stop processing if matched.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/security-zones.rst#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: OPNsense Configuration
CODE:
```
==============================================  ===================================================================================
**Action**                                      Pass
**Quick**                                       ``X``
**Interface**                                   any
**Direction**                                   in
**TCP/IP Version**                              IPv4
**Protocol**                                    ICMP
**Source**                                      ``TRUST net, UNTRUST net, WIFI net``
**Source port**                                 any
**Destination**                                 ``TRUST net, UNTRUST net, WIFI net``
**Destination port**                            any
**Description**                                 Allow ICMP between TRUST, UNTRUST, WIFI
==============================================  ===================================================================================
```

TITLE: Defining Device Properties for Configuration in PHP
DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a function that returns an array of device configurations, including description, verbatim description, device name, and additional parameters. It is used to manage device attributes within the system configuration, facilitating access and manipulation of device data programmatically. Dependencies include PHP PHP array handling, with inputs being device identifiers and outputs structured as associative arrays.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/backend/legacy.rst#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: PHP
CODE:
```
function mymyplugin_devices()
{
    $devices = [];

    $devices[] = [
        'function' => 'function_name_to_configure',
        'names' => ['dev0' => [
            'descr' => 'descriptive text',
            'ifdescr' => 'verbatim description',
            'name' => 'dev0',
        ]],
        'pattern' => '^dev',
        'volatile' => true,
        'type' => 'bridge',
    ];

    return $devices;
}
```

TITLE: Visualizing Network Topology with nwdiag - nwdiag

Use within documentation tools like Sphinx with nwdiag extension to generate SVG/PNG representations; required dependencies include nwdiag and appropriate documentation toolchains.

LANGUAGE: nwdiag
CODE:
```
nwdiag {

  span_width = 90;
  node_width = 180;
  network A {
      address = "10.1.0.0/24";
      pclana [label="PC Site A\n10.1.0.20",shape="cisco.pc"];
      fwa [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="10.1.0.1/24"];
  }
  network Ext {
      address = "10.10.1.0/24";
      label = "Ext";
      fwa [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="10.10.1.1/24"];
      fwb [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="10.10.1.2/24"];
  }
  network B {
      address = "192.168.1.0/24"
      fwb [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="192.168.1.20"];
      pclanb [label="PC Site B\n192.168.1.20",shape="cisco.pc"];
  }


}
```

TITLE: Verifying Downloaded Image Authenticity with OpenSSL - Shell
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates using OpenSSL command-line utilities to decode a base64-encoded signature accompanying an OPNsense image archive and verify its SHA-256 hash against a distributed RSA public key. It requires OpenSSL installed and access to the image archive (image.bz2), its signature (image.bz2.sig), and the verifying public key (rsa.pub). The first command decodes the base64 signature to a temporary binary file, while the second verifies the image's SHA-256 hash using the decoded signature and the provided public key. A successful verification confirms that the image is authentic and unmodified; failure indicates either a corrupted or tampered file.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/releases/CE_18.1.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# openssl base64 -d -in image.bz2.sig -out /tmp/image.sig
# openssl dgst -sha256 -verify rsa.pub -signature /tmp/image.sig image.bz2
```

TITLE: Exposing Configuration Sections for High Availability via XMLRPC in PHP
DESCRIPTION: This snippet creates an array defining a configuration section for high availability synchronization. It specifies metadata such as description, section name, identifier, and optional services, enabling the plugin's configuration to be synchronized across system nodes. Dependencies include PHP arrays and gettext functions, and it is used to ensure plugin settings are consistent in HA setups.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/backend/legacy.rst#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: PHP
CODE:
```
function myplugin_xmlrpc_sync()
{
    $result = array();
    $result[] = array(
        'description' => gettext('My Plugin'),
        'section' => 'OPNsense.Myplugin',
        'id' => 'myplugin',
        'services' => 'myplugin', // optional, in case a service with the same name exists
    );
    return $result;
}
```

TITLE: Understanding reply-to in pf Rules (Multi-WAN)
DESCRIPTION: `reply-to` is a directive used in OPNsense's packet filter (`pf`) rules, primarily in Multi-WAN scenarios. It ensures that reply traffic for a connection exits the same interface the initial packet arrived on, which helps prevent asymmetric routing issues. OPNsense adds this to WAN rules by default, but it can have side effects.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/firewall_settings.rst#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: pf
CODE:
```
reply-to
```

TITLE: Using while and do-while Loops in PHP
DESCRIPTION: Shows the syntax and formatting rules for while and do-while loops. The examples emphasize multi-line expressions in loop conditions, proper placement of parentheses, spacing, and indentation. The do-while loop example illustrates code execution at least once before condition evaluation. No dependencies are needed. The condition expressions can be boolean combinations, written across multiple lines following strict indentation and operators placement rules.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_19

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

while ($expr) {
    // structure body
}
```

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

while (
    $expr1
    && $expr2
) {
    // structure body
}
```

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

do {
    // structure body;
} while ($expr);
```

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

do {
    // structure body;
} while (
    $expr1
    && $expr2
);
```

TITLE: Adding Firewall Rule - OPNsense IPsec Host to LAN - Configuration
DESCRIPTION: Defines a firewall rule on the `IPsec` interface allowing TCP and UDP traffic from a specific roadwarrior host alias (`host_pool_roadwarrior_john`) to the LAN network alias (`LAN net`). This provides granular access control, permitting only designated roadwarriors to access LAN resources.

LANGUAGE: OPNsense Configuration
CODE:
```
    ==============================================  ====================================================================================================
    **Action**                                      Pass
    **Interface**                                   IPsec
    **Direction**                                   In
    **TCP/IP Version**                              IPv4+IPv6
    **Protocol**                                    TCP/UDP
    **Source**                                      ``host_pool_roadwarrior_john``
    **Source port**                                 Any
    **Destination**                                 ``LAN net``
    **Destination port**                            Any
    **Description**                                 Allow ``john@vpn1.example.com`` access to LAN net
    ==============================================  ====================================================================================================
```

TITLE: Formatting Trait Conflict Resolution Operators `insteadof` and `as` (PHP)
DESCRIPTION: Provides an example of the correct formatting for using the `insteadof` and `as` operators within PHP trait `use` statements to resolve method name conflicts. Note the specific indentation, spacing, and placement of new lines.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

class Talker
{
    use A;
    use B {
        A::smallTalk insteadof B;
    }
    use C {
        B::bigTalk insteadof C;
        C::mediumTalk as FooBar;
    }
}
```

TITLE: Defining Service Actions in OPNsense Configd (INI)
DESCRIPTION: This configuration defines the actions (start, stop, restart, reload, status) for the 'helloworld' service within the OPNsense configd system. Each action specifies a command, parameters, type, and message. These actions are simulated here using 'exit 0' and 'echo'.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/examples/api_enable_services.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: INI
CODE:
```
[start]
command:exit 0
parameters:
type:script
message:hello world service start

[stop]
command:exit 0
parameters:
type:script
message:hello world service stop

[restart]
command:exit 0
parameters:
type:script
message:hello world service restart

[reload]
command:exit 0
parameters:
type:script
message:hello world service restart

[status]
command: echo "hello world is running"
parameters:
type:script_output
message:hello world service status
```

This list defines allowed client source IP ranges, specifically common private IPv4 networks (192.168.0.0/16, 172.16.0.0/12, 10.0.0.0/8), intended to restrict access from the public internet.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/caddy.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: Text
CODE:
```
============================== ============================================================
Options                        Values
============================== ============================================================
**Access List Name:**          ``private_ipv4``
**Client IP Addresses:**       ``192.168.0.0/16`` ``172.16.0.0/12`` ``10.0.0.0/8``
**Description:**               ``Allow access from private IPv4 ranges``
============================== ============================================================
```

TITLE: Using opnsense-revert to rollback packages and system versions
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to revert individual packages like 'strongswan' to a previous version or rollback the entire system to an earlier release using the opnsense-revert utility. It provides command examples for reverting packages to a specific release and for reverting the full system, including kernel downgrades. It emphasizes checking for kernel updates when performing reversion.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/opnsense_tools.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
# opnsense-revert -r 18.1.4 strongswan

# opnsense-revert strongswan

# opnsense-revert -r 18.1.4 opnsense
```

TITLE: Multiline Interface Implementation in PHP

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php
namespace Vendor\Package;

use FooClass;
use BarClass as Bar;
use OtherVendor\OtherPackage\BazClass;

    \ArrayAccess,
    \Countable,
    \Serializable
{
    // constants, properties, methods
}
```

TITLE: Filtering Stacks and Generating Specific Flame Graph (Shell/Perl)
DESCRIPTION: Filters the folded stack data (`out.kern_folded`) using `grep` to select only stack traces containing 'cpuid'. The filtered output is then piped to the `flamegraph.pl` script to generate an SVG Flame Graph (`cpuid.svg`) visualizing only the code paths related to `cpuid`. Requires the FlameGraph toolkit.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/how-tos/dtrace.rst#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
# grep cpuid out.kern_folded | ./flamegraph.pl > cpuid.svg
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Verifying OPNsense Image Signature using OpenSSL (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to verify the SHA256 signature of a downloaded OPNsense image file (`image.bz2`) using its corresponding signature file (`image.bz2.sig`) and the OPNsense public key (`rsa.pub`). The first command decodes the base64 encoded signature file, and the second performs the SHA256 verification using the public key against the image file. Requires OpenSSL to be installed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/releases/CE_17.7.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# openssl base64 -d -in image.bz2.sig -out /tmp/image.sig
# openssl dgst -sha256 -verify rsa.pub -signature /tmp/image.sig image.bz2
```

TITLE: Configuring Active Response Rules in Wazuh Manager
DESCRIPTION: XML configuration example showing how to set up active response rules in the Wazuh manager. This example configures the manager to execute the 'opnsense-fw' command on a specific agent when rule 87702 is triggered.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/wazuh-agent.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: xml
CODE:
```
<ossec_config>
  <active-response>
    <disabled>no</disabled>
    <command>opnsense-fw</command>
    <location>defined-agent</location>
    <agent_id>001</agent_id>
    <rules_id>87702</rules_id>
    <timeout>180</timeout>
  </active-response>
</ossec_config>
```

TITLE: Starting VMware Guest Services using Syshook early script (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an example of a shell script intended for the 'early' syshook directory (/usr/local/etc/rc.syshook.d/early/). It enables various VMware guest service options by exporting environment variables and then executes the corresponding rc.d script to start the services before the main network startup.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/backend/autorun.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: Shell
CODE:
```
#!/bin/sh

export vmware_guest_vmblock_enable="YES"
export vmware_guest_vmhgfs_enable="YES"
export vmware_guest_vmmemctl_enable="YES"
export vmware_guest_vmxnet_enable="YES"

/usr/local/etc/rc.d/vmware-kmod start
```

TITLE: Defining PHP UI Controller to Connect View and Form Dialog
DESCRIPTION: Implements the UI controller class inheriting from OPNsense Base IndexController. It specifies the Volt template to render and loads the XML form definition for the address dialog to be made available in the view. This controller enables the binding of data and user interface components in the MVC pattern within OPNsense.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/examples/using_grids.rst#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: PHP
CODE:
```
namespace OPNsense\GridExample;

class IndexController extends \OPNsense\Base\IndexController
{
    public function indexAction()
    {
        $this->view->pick('OPNsense/GridExample/index');
        $this->view->formDialogAddress = $this->getForm("dialogAddress");
    }
}

```

```
    }
```
```
}
```

TITLE: Certificate Bundle PEM Structure
DESCRIPTION: This snippet depicts the structure of a PEM formatted certificate bundle, combining the public keys of the Root CA, Intermediate CA, and Leaf Certificate. It's used to ensure the webserver presents the full certificate chain to clients. The PEM format is a widely used container format for cryptographic keys and certificates.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/self-signed-chain.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
Root CA public key data
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
Intermediate CA public key data
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
Leaf Certificate public key data
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
```

TITLE: Verifying SHA256 Checksums for OPNsense Firmware Images in Shell
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides commented examples of SHA256 checksums for various OPNsense 15.1.11.1 firmware images, intended for manual verification after downloading installation media. No external dependencies are required except standard SHA256 utilities available on UNIX-like systems. Each line specifies the filename and its expected SHA256 hash. System administrators compare these hashes against computed values to ensure file integrity and authenticity before installation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/releases/CE_15.1.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# SHA256 (OPNsense-15.1.11.1_OpenSSL-cdrom-amd64.iso.bz2) = 280f02a2da3ff9e9ad1f655a8661c845765493f36e1788b8c852af9886c50316
# SHA256 (OPNsense-15.1.11.1_OpenSSL-nano-amd64.img.bz2) = 2d14d881311ca8b188a41a2d57aee6e0bec66f55066f2844502d4ef17e64935e
```

TITLE: Verifying OPNsense Image Signature using OpenSSL (Bash)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to verify the SHA256 signature of a downloaded OPNsense image file (`image.bz2`) using its corresponding signature file (`image.bz2.sig`) and the public RSA key (`rsa.pub`). The first command decodes the base64 signature, and the second performs the verification.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/releases/CE_18.1.rst#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
# openssl base64 -d -in image.bz2.sig -out /tmp/image.sig
# openssl dgst -sha256 -verify rsa.pub -signature /tmp/image.sig image.bz2
```

```
Under the Authentication section, set the Server dropdown to the LDAP server you added
Save the settings

- Assign appropriate privileges to ensure local or remote access
- Keep local database as a fallback option to prevent lockouts
```

TITLE: Verifying a valid certificate using OCSP with OpenSSL

This command returns the status of the certificate (good, revoked, or unknown).

```
# openssl ocsp -url http://127.0.0.1:8081 -CAfile ca.crt -issuer ca.crt -serial 1
Response verify OK
1: good
	    This Update: Jan  6 13:33:59 2024 GMT
```

TITLE: Anonymous Class Declaration in PHP

SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_27

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

$instance = new class {};
```

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

// Brace on the same line
$instance = new class extends \Foo implements \HandleableInterface {
    // Class content
};
```

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

// Brace on the next line
$instance = new class extends \Foo implements
    \ArrayAccess,
    \Countable,
    \Serializable
{
    // Class content
};
```

TITLE: Testing nginx TLS Authentication Without Client Certificate (curl)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates a `curl` command attempting to access a resource protected by TLS client authentication without providing a client certificate. This results in an HTTP 400 error because the required certificate is missing. The `--cacert` option specifies the CA certificate to verify the server's certificate.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/nginx_tls_auth.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
curl https://192.168.1.1:444/file.txt --cacert ../MyOPNsenseCA.crt
```

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
<html>
<head><title>400 No required SSL certificate was sent</title></head>
<body bgcolor="white">
<center><h1>400 Bad Request</h1></center>
<center>No required SSL certificate was sent</center>
<hr><center>nginx</center>
</body>
</html>
```

TITLE: Ordering `abstract`, `final`, `static`, and Visibility Keywords (PHP)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the required order for declaration keywords in PHP classes and methods. `abstract` and `final` MUST precede visibility (`protected`, `public`). `static` MUST come after visibility.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

namespace Vendor\Package;

abstract class ClassName
{
    protected static $foo;

    abstract protected function zim();

    final public static function bar()
    {
        // method body
    }
}
```

TITLE: Defining an OPNsense Model Structure in XML
DESCRIPTION: Provides an example XML structure for defining an OPNsense model, corresponding to the PHP class. It includes the `<mount>` point in the configuration file, `<description>`, `<version>`, and `<items>` defining the data fields. Fields include types (TextField, ArrayField, EmailField), validation rules (Mask, ValidationMessage), and default values. This file should have the same base name as the model class and reside in the same directory.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/models_design.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: xml
CODE:
```
<model>
    <mount>//myManufacturer/myModule</mount>
    <description>A description of this model (metadata)</description>
    <version>1.0.0</version>
    <items>
        <exampleNumber type="TextField">
            <Mask>/^([0-9]){0,1}$/</Mask>
            <Default>5</Default>
            <ValidationMessage>you should input a number from 0 to 9</ValidationMessage>
        </exampleNumber>
        <contacts>
            <entity type="ArrayField">
                <email type="EmailField">
                    <ValidationMessage>you should input a valid email address!</ValidationMessage>
                </email>
                <name type="TextField"/>
            </entity>
            <someText type="TextField"/>
        </contacts>
    </items>
</model>
```

TITLE: SHA256 Checksums for OPNsense Images
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet contains SHA256 checksums for verifying the integrity of OPNsense installation images. Users can compare these values with the checksum of their downloaded image to ensure it hasn't been corrupted during the download process. This is a critical security step before installation. The input is the downloaded image, and the output is the calculated SHA256 hash for comparison.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/releases/CE_15.1.rst#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
# SHA256 (OPNsense-15.1.9-cdrom-amd64.iso.bz2) = d159a791cbc373435f25c74f433cc6b419fd8d6df8940d854fec6cd07545acd4
# SHA256 (OPNsense-15.1.9-serial-amd64.img.bz2) = 0584fa5092c40af9f8523be527408af57eac2ca71c9522e8167f7ae7f08e0586
# SHA256 (OPNsense-15.1.9-vga-amd64.img.bz2) = ccd550b471aa6b13d9a8921aa9461d5eddedaeb9c375e97261ff4e54ebd881d2
```

TITLE: Formatting Method Return Type Declarations (PHP)
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to format return type declarations in PHP methods using `declare(strict_types=1)`. There MUST be one space after the colon (`:`) followed by the type. The colon and type declaration MUST be on the same line as the closing parenthesis of the argument list.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

declare(strict_types=1);

namespace Vendor\Package;

class ReturnTypeVariations
{
    public function functionName(int $arg1, $arg2): string
    {
        return 'foo';
    }

    public function anotherFunction(
        string $foo,
        string $bar,
        int $baz
    ): string {
        return 'foo';
    }
}
```

The closing parenthesis and opening brace MUST be on their own line together, separated by one space.

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
<?php

namespace Vendor\Package;

class ClassName
{
    public function aVeryLongMethodName(
        ClassTypeHint $arg1,
        &$arg2,
        array $arg3 = []
    ) {
        // method body
    }
}
```

TITLE: Capturing uiomove Entry Stack Traces with DTrace (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: Executes a DTrace one-liner to trace the entry point of the `uiomove` kernel function. ```

TITLE: Defining Network Diagram for IPSec BINAT Topology (nwdiag)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet uses the nwdiag diagram definition language to visualize the network topology for the IPSec BINAT configuration. It depicts the two local LANs (LAN A and LAN B), the substitute 'Tunnel networks' (NATA and NATB) used for the IPSec Phase 2 definition, and abstract 'Virtual net' nodes connecting them. It illustrates the conceptual flow between the real networks and the virtual tunnel networks.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-s2s-binat.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: nwdiag
CODE:
```
nwdiag {

  span_width = 90;
  node_width = 180;

  network LANA {
    label = " LAN Site A";
    address ="10.0.1.0/24";
    lana [label="Network A"];
  }

  network NATA {
    label = " Tunnel network";
    address ="192.168.1.0/24";
    lana [label="Network A"];
    virtuala [label="Virtual net A", shape = cloud];
  }

  network NATB {
    label = " Tunnel network";
    address ="192.168.2.0/24";
    virtuala [label="Virtual net A", shape = cloud]
    virtualb [label="Virtual net B", shape = cloud];
  }

  network LANB  {
    label = " LAN Site B";
    virtualb [label="Virtual net B", shape = cloud];
    lanb [label="Network B"];
  }

}
```

TITLE: Creating and Configuring Web Application Directory (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a directory for a web application, check its permissions, and modify them to allow access for NGINX and PHP (running as the `www` user). It uses `mkdir`, `cd`, `stat`, and `chmod` commands.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/nginx_hosting.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
# create a directory
mkdir -p /srv/web_application1
cd /srv
stat web_application1
# Example Result:
# 86 18009 drwxr-xr-x 2 root wheel 14050 512 "Aug 31 18:28:19 2018" 
#  "Aug 31 18:28:19 2018" "Aug 31 18:28:19 2018" "Aug 31 18:28:19 2018"
#  32768 8 0 web_application1
#
# as you can see, everyone can read (r) and switch into the directory (x))
#
# do this if the directory is not readable or excutable:
chmod +rx web_application1
```

TITLE: Configuring make.conf for Userspace DTrace Frame Pointers (Shell)
DESCRIPTION: Adds `STRIP=` and `CFLAGS+=-fno-omit-frame-pointer` to `/usr/tools/conf/[VERSION]/make.conf`. Setting `STRIP=` prevents symbol stripping, and adding `-fno-omit-frame-pointer` to CFLAGS ensures frame pointers are retained in compiled userspace binaries, which is necessary for enabling DTrace analysis in userspace applications.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/how-tos/dtrace.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: sh
CODE:
```
STRIP=
CFLAGS+=-fno-omit-frame-pointer
```

TITLE: Implementing a Custom Field Type for Legacy Data Conversion in PHP
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates a custom field type `PrivField` extending `BaseListField` within an OPNsense model. It overrides `actionPostLoadingEvent` to populate dropdown options by fetching ACL privileges and overrides `setValue` to handle `SimpleXMLElement` input specifically. If multiple `<priv>` tags are detected during loading from legacy XML, it merges them into a single comma-separated string for the model field. This pattern facilitates converting structured legacy data into a model-compatible format.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/frontend/models_design.rst#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
class PrivField extends BaseListField
{
   protected $internalIsContainer = false;
   private static $priv_list = null;

   protected function actionPostLoadingEvent()
   {
      if (self::$priv_list === null) {
            self::$priv_list = [];
            foreach ((new \OPNsense\Core\ACL())->getPrivList() as $aclKey => $priv) {
               self::$priv_list[$aclKey] = $priv['name'];
            }

      }
      $this->internalOptionList = self::$priv_list;
   }

   /**
   * {@inheritdoc}
   */
   public function setValue($value)
   {
      if (is_a($value, 'SimpleXMLElement') && $value->count() > 1) {
            return parent::setValue(implode(',', (array)$value));
      } else {
            return parent::setValue($value);
      }
   }
}
```

TITLE: Formatting Reference Variadic Arguments (PHP)
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the correct formatting when combining the reference operator (`&`) and the variadic three-dot operator (`...`) in PHP function/method arguments. There MUST NOT be any space between the `&` and the `...` (e.g., `&...$parts`).
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/development/guidelines/psr12.rst#_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: php
CODE:
```
public function process(string $algorithm, &...$parts)
{
    // processing
}
```

TITLE: Configuring DHCP Send Options for VLAN 838 on OPNsense
DESCRIPTION: Specifies the DHCP options to be sent by the OPNsense client when requesting an IP address on VLAN 838 for Orange IPTV. It includes the client identifier derived from the Livebox MAC address (prefixed with '1:'), the class identifier set to 'sagem', and the user class string identifying the Livebox model ('FSVDSL_livebox.MLTV.softathome.Livebox3' or similar). These options are crucial for authentication with Orange's network.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/orange_fr_tvf.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
dhcp-client-identifier 1:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx,
dhcp-class-identifier "sagem",
user-class "'FSVDSL_livebox.MLTV.softathome.Livebox3".
```

TITLE: Defining a Sample Network Topology using nwdiag
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet utilizes the nwdiag tool to generate a network diagram representing the sample setup used throughout the IPsec remote access guides. It defines network segments (LAN, WAN, Remote), devices (firewall, file server, switch, laptop), their interconnections, IP addresses, and labels. The diagram visualizes the environment for which the subsequent OPNsense IPsec configurations are designed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-rw.rst#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: nwdiag
CODE:
```
  :scale: 100%

    nwdiag {

      span_width = 90;
      node_width = 180;
      Internet [shape = "cisco.cloud"];
      fileserver [label="File Server",shape="cisco.fileserver",address="192.168.1.10"];
      fileserver -- switchlan;

      network LAN {
        switchlan [label="",shape = "cisco.workgroup_switch"];
        label = " LAN";
        address ="192.168.1.x/24";
        fw1 [address="192.168.1.1/24"];
      }

      network WAN  {
        label = " WAN";
        fw1 [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="172.18.0.164"];
        Internet;
      }

      network Remote {
          Internet;
          laptop [address="172.10.10.55 (WANIP),10.10.0.1 (IPsec)",label="Remote User",shape="cisco.laptop"];
      }
    }
```

TITLE: Configuring NCP Secure Entry Client Profile via Ini File
DESCRIPTION: Provides an example configuration file (`example.ini`) for the NCP Secure Entry Client (v13.14). This file defines profile settings such as connection name (`Name`), gateway (`Gateway`), IKEv2 policies (`IKEv2Policy`, `IkeDhGroup`), IPsec policies (`IPSec-Policy`, `PFS`), authentication method (EAP - implied by `IKEv2Auth=3`), user identity (`IkeIdStr`), IP address assignment, DNS settings, and security parameters. This template requires customization of `Name`, `Gateway`, and `IkeIdStr` for the specific user and VPN server before importing into the NCP client.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/ipsec-swanctl-rw-ikev2-eap-mschapv2.rst#_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: ini
CODE:
```
[GENERAL]
Export=1
Product=NCP Secure Entry Client
Version=13.14 Build 29669
Date=11.09.2023 09:30:42
[PROFILE1]
Name=vpn1.example.com
ConnMedia=21
UseForAuto=0
SeamRoaming=1
NotKeepVpn=0
BootProfile=0
UseRAS=0
SavePw=0
PhoneNumber=
DialerPhone=
ScriptFile=
HttpName=
HttpPw=
HttpScript=
Modem=
ComPort=1
Baudrate=57600
RelComPort=1
InitStr=
DialPrefix=
3GApnSrc=2
3GProvider=
APN=
3GPhone=
3GAuth=0
GprsATCmd=AT+CPIN=
GprsPin=""
BiometricAuth=0
PreAuthEap=0
PreAuthHttp=0
ConnMode=0
Timeout=0
TunnelTrafficMonitoring=0
TunnelTrafficMonitoringAddr=0.0.0.0
QoS=none
PkiConfig=
ExchMode=34
TunnelIpVersion=1
IKEv2Auth=3
IKE-Policy=automatic mode
IKEv2Policy=aes256-sha256
IkeDhGroup=14
IkeLTSec=000:00:40:00
IPSec-Policy=aes256-sha256
PFS=14
IPSecLTType=1
IpsecLTSec=000:00:10:00
IPSecLTKb=50000
UseComp=0
IkeIdType=3
IkeIdStr=john@vpn1.example.com
Gateway=vpn1.example.com
ConnType=1
UsePreShKey=0
XAUTH-Src=0
SplitOptionV4=1
UseTunnel=1
SplitOptionV6=1
VpnBypass=none
UseXAUTH=1
UseUdpEnc=500
UseUdpEncTmp=4500
DisDPD=0
DPDInterval=30
DPDRetrys=8
AntiReplay=0
PathFinder=0
UseRFC7427=1
RFC7427Padding=2
Ikev2AuthPrf=0
CertReqWithData=0
IpAddrAssign=0
IPAddress=
SubnetMask=
DNS1=
DNS2=
DomainName=
DomainInTunnel=
SubjectCert=
IssuerCert=
FingerPrint=
UseSHA1=0
Firewall=0
OnlyTunnel=0
RasOnlyTunnel=0
DNSActiv=1
DNS1Tmp=
DNS2Tmp=
[IKEV2POLICY1]
Ikev2Name=aes256-sha256
Ikev2Crypt=6
Ikev2PRF=5
Ikev2IntAlgo=12
[IPSECPOLICY1]
IPSecName=aes256-sha256
IpsecCrypt=6
IpsecAuth=5
```

TITLE: Describing Filter and Search Features with HTML Markup
DESCRIPTION: HTML markup explaining the filter functionality in OPNsense grids, including the search input, reload button, and pagination features. Details how the search tokenizes input and provides contextual navigation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/gui.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: html
CODE:
```
The top area of the grid contains a search input combined with a reload button <i class="fa fa-reload"></i> and
a selection for the number of rows to show at once on a page. Often the search input will be instantly applied, but
in some cases a reload is needed if the action can't be processed fast enough.
<br/><br/>
When using the filter in log files, you will find a <i class="fa fa-arrow-right"></i> <b>Go to page</b> action
behind every record. This will jump to the corresponding page and show you all surrounding records so you can see
the context of a log message.
<br/><br/>
```

TITLE: Network Topology Diagram for VPN Tunnel
DESCRIPTION: This code defines a network topology diagram using the nwdiag tool, illustrating the setup of two networks (A and B) connected via a transit network. It visualizes the firewalls (fwA, fwB), PCs (pclana, pclanb), and their respective IP addresses, clarifying the network segments used for the site-to-site VPN tunnel.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/manual/how-tos/sslvpn_instance_s2s.rst#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: nwdiag
CODE:
```
nwdiag {

      span_width = 90;
      node_width = 180;
      network A {
          address = "10.0.8.0/24";
          pclana [label="PC Site A\n10.0.8.20",shape="cisco.pc"];
          fwa [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="10.0.8.1/24"];
      }
      network Ext {
          address = "WAN net 10.10.8.0/24";
          label = "Tunnel net 10.1.8.0/24";
          fwa [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="10.10.8.1/24"];
          fwb [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="10.10.8.2/24"];
      }
      network B {
          address = "192.168.8.0/24"
          fwb [shape = "cisco.firewall", address="192.168.8.20"];
          pclanb [label="PC Site B\n192.168.8.20",shape="cisco.pc"];
      }


    }
```

TITLE: Validating OPNsense 17.1 Images Using MD5 Checksums - Shell
DESCRIPTION: This snippet lists sample shell comments containing MD5 checksums for the different OPNsense 17.1 installation images, enabling integrity verification by matching the published MD5 sums with those calculated locally using 'md5 <filename>'. The approach helps detect incomplete or tampered downloads. The only dependency is the md5 command-line tool. MD5 is less secure than SHA256; users are encouraged to use SHA256 if possible, and ensure the image filenames match before comparing values.
SOURCE: https://github.com/opnsense/docs/blob/master/source/releases/CE_17.1.rst#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: shell
CODE:
```
# MD5 (OPNsense-17.1-OpenSSL-cdrom-amd64.iso.bz2) = b39a8440377b6a2aae5832e3caea23d7
# MD5 (OPNsense-17.1-OpenSSL-nano-amd64.img.bz2) = 583c7d4a4c4263d51e0fa153f8c021e4
```
